titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Isaac Doty papers 1977.495
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:11:17 +0000.

did.abstract: Deeds, agreements, and receipts of Isaac Doty, a resident of New York City who lived at the corner of Oak and Pearl Streets. There is also one letter to Doty from his nephew, Benjamin Doughty of the town of Jericho in Queens County. One deed involves William Doughty, who is presumed to also be a family relative of Isaac Doty. Items span 1797 to 1823.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related archival collections at the Brooklyn Historical Society:
